pageContent:
How are honey bees built? 
Anatomy and Physiology 
I 
(
end of 
Lecture 5
) 
By the end of this lecture, you should be able to: 
• 
Sketch a 
honey bee
, locate its basic body parts, and know their function 
• 
Explain why the exoskeleton is remarkable, yet recognize some of the 
drawbacks of having an external skeleton 
• 
Contrast key sensory organs (sight, smell, taste, and touch) 
• 
Compare bee vision and human vision 
• 
Explain how 
honey bees 
walk, and how they fly

Antennae
 
 
2 antennae
Responsible for smell — has a lot of olfactory receptors in different areas of the antenna
Responsible for touch — has a lot of mechanoreceptors 
few taste receptors as well, but main taste receptors are somewhere else

Mouthparts 
o
 
Mandibles 
used for 
cutting, shaping, 
manipulating wax 
o
 
Proboscis 
includes 
Glossa 
(tongue) 
covered by hairs that 
stick to nectar or 
water 
Proboscis is folded under 
the head and extended 
when in use 
https://canvas.cornell.edu/courses/8456/modules/items/511663 
(cleaning of tongue
-
30 sec) 
Very good at catching liquids
Can’t be seen most of the time, tucked under head; 
extends entire proboscis to gather nectar etc.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xoCn9XDVI0A&ab_channel= 
PaleontologicalResearchInstitution

The proboscis is 
Used for: 
Ingestion of liquid (nectar, honey, water). 
Mouth
-
to
-
mouth exchange of fluids 
They kind of lap like cats 
(trophallaxis)

Glands in head 
salivary glands: similar to ours, secrets all kinds of enzymes that are 
important for digestion
Hypopharyngeal gland:
Extremely important for 
producing food, that is 
given to larvae
mandibular gland:
produces pheromones, 
volatile or not, 
That are used for 
infraspecific 
communication (bw 
members of same 
species)
Remember what these three glands are and where they are

Thorax
•
3 pairs of legs
•
2 pairs of wings
•
Large 
musculature to 
support walking 
and flying

Legs
foreleg
hindleg
midleg
all these legs have the same structure with 
five big segments (coxa, trochanter, femur, 
tibia, basitarsus) and many, many, many 
little torsi

Fore
leg
-
contain
 
antenna cleaner
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tQKF9rTaYTo
And lot of 
hairs that brush 
proboscis

10
Hind leg
-
include 
corbicula
This is the tibia
have an enlarged tibia on their hind leg and this is where they keep the pollen pellet
Once they gather all those pollen grains, Thye need a system to actually carry that back to their colony
going to be stuck on the outside of the hind leg in that concave area which we call the corbicula
have really long hairs on 
corbicula that help keep 
pellet in place during mid 
flight

How do honey bees walk?
•
Honeybees walk with all six legs 
•
Alternating tripod
L       R
L       R
stance
swing
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5wzd1QssrVE
If you removed one of the bee’s midlegs:
The bee would probably be unable to maintain perfect 
balance and would wobble when walking

Wings
Forewing and hindwing
Hooked together for flight
By 
hooks
 
called 
hamuli
wings are made of exoskeleton; a very thin cuticle that is actually braced with veins

How do 
bees
 
fly?
Definitely NOT like birds!

Two sets of indirect 
flight muscles: DLM 
and DVM
Indirect flight 
muscles don’t attach 
to the wings.
They deform the 
thorax, causing wings 
to flap  (go up or 
down)
DLM
DVM
DVM
ventral
Thorax  
-
  
cross section
Indirect flight muscles
PWP
 
(fulcrum)
dorsal
 
https://www.youtube.com/w
atch?v=yRE2rMIXvyU

When 
DVM muscles 
contract, 
top of thorax is pulled down => wings go up
When 
DLM muscles 
contract, 
thorax is squeezed front
-
to
-
back, top pops up
 
 
 
 
 
     
=> wings go down
PWP
(fulcrum)
PWP
(fulcrum)
Direct flight muscles cause wings to go back and forth
when indirect and direct combine= figure 8 movement

Direct flight muscles control direction
L
e
g
•
Two sets of direct flight 
muscles
•
They pull on small bits
  
of cuticle (sclerites) at     
the wing base
•
tilts the front edge of the 
wing down or  tilts the 
back edge of the wing 
down
DLM
DVM
DVM
ventral
Thorax  
-
  
cross section
Indirect flight muscles
PWP
 
(fulcrum)
dorsal
 
Direct
flight muscles
Direct
flight muscles
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yRE2rMIXvyU&ab_channel=LiveScience

Glands on legs
Remember the name and location of these 2^

How 
are 
honey bees
 
built?
 
Anatomy and Physiology 
II
(Lecture
 
6
)
By the end of this lecture, you should be able to:
Know the name/function of bee’s internal body parts (ex: 
Malpighian tubules, trachea, fat body, etc.)
Explain how 
honey bees
 
“breathe”
Contrast their 
haemolymph
 
with the vertebrate blood
Summarize how 
honey bees
 
process food, from ingestion to 
excretion
Understand that 
honey bees
 
have a gut microbiome that is 
important for their overall health
Recognize that they have an Immune system, and remarkable 
cognitive abilities that would put your favorite dog or cat to 
shame

Abdomen
•
Nine segments but 
Seven visible ones
•
Each segment has 
two circular 
openings on flanks 
(spiracles)
•
Contains most of 
the internal organs
•
Contains the sting 
(in females)

Circulatory system
-
Haemolymph
 
circulates
 
freely around the internal
 
organs
, and mediates
 
all chemical exchanges
 
-
There 
is ONE 
vessel
(dorsal
 
vessel
)
-
Muscular contractions
 
of parts of the body move 
 
the fluid.
-
Does not have respiratory 
 
pigments (no carrying of O2) 
not red
Haemolymph is floating freely, not like our vessels
Circulates from back to front

A close look at the dorsal vessel in a recently 
molted juvenile of a very distant cousin of 
honey bees, the  giant water bug

-
Esophagus: keeps food and liquids move along
-
Crop
 
(AKA honey crop)
: ingestion, storage, grinding
-
Proventricular valve: 
control of flow from crop to midgut
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
and filtration
Digestive system
proboscis
mandibles
crop- kind of like a stomach, can hold lot of water, nectar, honeyl
Can block so everything can stay in crop
midgut
 similar to our small intestine;
Absorption occurs here, carbs become monosachharaides, 
protein become amino acids,
Fats become simpler lipids that can be directly taken into cells
Illeum and rectum are 
collectively known as 
hindgut
Illeum- narrow tube bw 
mid gut and rectum and 
responsible for absorbing 
a lot of the salt back from 
the result of the digestion 
and reabsorbtion of water
rectum - where piuch are 
made and eventually 
excreted thru anus
•
it is like a pouch that 
can expand (like the 
honey crop) and it can 
accumulate a fair 
amount of feces
Ileum

-
Midgut
 
(AKA ventriculus)
: 
digestive 
enzymes present, 
absorption
 
occurs
 
Carbohydrates become monosaccharides
 
Proteins become amino acids
 
Fats become glycerol and fatty acids

-
Midgut opens into 
Ileum and 
Rectum
 
(=
hindgut
)
 
-
ileum absorbs salts and water back from waste
 
-
rectum
 
is
 
site
 
of
 
feces formation and accumulation
Ileum

-
Malpighian tubules 
(~100!) absorb 
Nitrogenous waste from 
hemolymph, produce a 
filtrate
 
that is excreted 
through the rectum
 
Malpighian tubules
Midgut
Proventricular 
valve
rectum
Bw midgut and ileum

Fat bodies (white), reduced in a “summer bee” forager (left), fully 
developed in a “winter bee” (right). 
If there is extra food: storage in fat bodies 
under the floor and roof of the abdomen 
Note: the fat body is not JUST body fat! 
It is 
a complex 
organ in itself
 
(ex: immune 
function, detoxification)
keep feces inside for 
long periods during 
winter and waits till 
relatively warm day 
to defecate in mass

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S2214574517301761
Distribution 
of
bacterial communities
in the 
honey bee
 
worker 
gut
Honey bees
 
have a gut microbiome
Their gut 
microbiome is 
found in the ileum 
and rectum

-
Insects must obtain 
o
xygen 
and eliminate 
c
arbon 
dioxide
-
This gas exchange 
occurs by means of
 
internal air
-
filled 
tracheae
-
Air enters through 
spiracles and is 
distributed by several
trachea
e
Respiratory system
No lungs — instead have a network of tubes called 
trachea
o2 comes in thru spiracles (openings on sides of abdomen) and then it enters 
this network of tubes; big and become thinner and thinner until they become 
tracheoles. Tracheoles plug into cells and directly sends 02 there

•
Movement
-
assisted air flow 
(“breathing”)
•
Adaptations for more effective air 
supply during flight, 
i.e.
 
high 
oxygen expenditure.
•
Under  stress,  such  as  during  
flight, bees
 
 
pump their abdomens    
to increase  gas  exchange  and  
expand air sacs of the trachea like  
bellows, facilitating greater gas 
exchange.
from Snodgrass ca. 1935
Air sacs in the honeybee
Air 
sacs

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1rvxD2og
3Xg&t=10s

Nervous system
Consists of:
•
a brain
•
a ventral nerve cord 
running from head to 
end of abdomen
•
7 ganglia at various 
junctions throughout 
the body along that 
nerve cord
Note
: a 
ganglion
=a structure containing 
a number of
 
nerve cell bodies, typically 
linked by synapses, and often forming a swelling on a nerve fiber.
brain
Ventral nerve cord
One of the 
7 ganglia
made up of 
all kinds of 
ganglia

•
Function 1 
is to receive sensory information from 
compound eyes, antennae and mouthparts
•
Three separate brain regions for this: Optic lobe 
OL, antennal lobe AL, Suboesophageal ganglion 
SEG 
(
no need to remember those compartments)
Bees have a “brain” but it barely 
resembles a human brain.

•
Function 2
 
is learning and memory
•
Mushroom bodies MB are important in a bee's ability to 
learn, remember and act on that sensory information.

•
Most locomotion is 
controlled by the 
ganglia not the brain.
brain
The last 
of 7 ganglia
What happens if you cut the head of a honey bee?
it will keep moving its legs and abdomen (can 
still walk and sting; can not fly)

A s
mall and simple
 
brain
, 
but 
still enough 
for 
sophisticated
 
cognitive 
abilities
Only ~ 1 million neurons
But enough for:
-
Fast computing
-
Understanding conceptual 
relationships
-
Having a 
cognitive
 
metric map
-
Associative learning

Remember 1890’s 
Pavlov’s 
experiments with 
salivating dogs, 
metronomes, and 
food?
Honey bees are capable of Classical conditioning
(aka Pavlovian conditioning, or associative learning)

https://
ww
w.youtube.
com
/
watch
?v
=t1TiBLiL
_f4
The Proboscis Extension Reflex (PER) can be used to make workers pair a 
biologically potent stimulus (
e.g.
 
sugar solution) with a previously neutral 
stimulus (
e.g.
 
volatile odor). 
Honey bees
 
are capable of Classical conditioning
(aka Pavlovian conditioning, or associative learning)

Bumble
 
bees 
(
Bombus 
terrestris
) 
can 
learn to play 
soccer ....well, at least they can roll a ball ....

PLUS
 
these bumblebees can teach 
conspecific individuals to play soccer!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ToZDCo51c_I&ab_channel=
Quartz

The endocrine system includes the many glands scattered 
throughout the body that secrete chemicals with 4 main functions
•
Wax production
•
Communication (internal: hormones; external: pheromones)
•
Defense
•
Food processing  
Endocrine system

H
oney
 
bee
s even have 
an immune system
!

and it is very complex!
Immune system insects
2011 Nobel Prize
In Medicine
DO NOT STUDY FOR THIS CLASS!

Ecological Entomology, Volume: 42, Issue: S1, Pages: 51
-
64, First published: 29 August 2017, DOI: (10.1111/een.12434) 
Besides the immune system 
each individual
 
has, there is a 
SOCIAL IMMUNITY based on collective 
behaviours

Larval 
Honey bees
Mouthpart
